Condolences to Egyptian President
articles.content:
Condolences to Egyptian President 
    Pyongyang, January 5 (KCNA) -- Kim Yong Nam, president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, on Jan. 4 sent a message of condolence to Egyptian President Mohamed Hosni Mubarak as regards the recent airliner crash in Egypt that claimed many casualties.
 The message expressed deep condolences to the president and the bereaved families of the victims.

articles.title: Condolences to French President
articles.content:
Condolences to French President
    Pyongyang, January 5 (KCNA) -- Kim Yong Nam, president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, on Jan. 4 sent a message of condolence to French President Jacques Chirac as regards the recent airliner crash in Egypt that claimed lives of French people.
 The message expressed deep sympathy and condolences to the president and, through him, to the government and people of France and the bereaved families of the victims.

articles.title: Korean People's Cause Supported
Hong Chang Su Again Retains World Championship
articles.content:
Hong Chang Su Again Retains World Championship 
    Pyongyang, January 5 (KCNA) -- Hong Chang Su, Korean pro-boxer in Japan, scraped a 3-0 decision over challenger Dmitri Kirilov, the best boxer in Russia, in the super-flyweight match of the WBC held in Osaka, Japan on Jan. 3.
 He has thus retained his championship for the 8th time since his match held in June last year.

articles.title: Japanese Chief Executive's Visit to "Yasukuni Shrine" Denounced in S. Korea
articles.content:
Japanese Chief Executive's Visit to "Yasukuni Shrine" Denounced in S. Korea 
    Pyongyang, January 5 (KCNA) -- The Consultative Council for Earlier Compensation to the Victims of the Pacific War and other south Korean civic organizations held a protest rally in front of the Japanese embassy on Jan. 2 denouncing the Japanese chief executive's visit to the "Yasukuni Shrine", according to south Korean MBC.
 The organizations condemned the Japanese chief executive's visit to the "Yasukuni Shrine", which keeps the remains of the special-class war criminals of the Pacific war, on the New Year's day as an act little short of thrusting daggers into the hearts of the people killed by the Japanese militarists.    
 The Japanese chief executive talked about "peace" whenever he visited the shrine but, in fact, he took the lead in pushing the Japanese society to the Right, they said. And they demanded the south Korean authorities strongly react to it.
